column4: i'm currently using 6.10 and wanted to upgrade my GNUPG to latest release, i notice that there is no ubuntu package for the latest release but for 7.04 there is, is this what i should expect if i decide not to upgrade evrytime a new ubuntu is released?
Yup, exactly.  New ubuntu = newer versions of everything (new versions generally == annoying bugs fixed :))
hmm, perhaps i should take a look at debian, i dont want to have to upgrade my server with every ubuntu release
Indeed.  You might want debian, but unless you use Unstable, you'll be generally getting *older* versions :)
Yes, indeed.  It's not a release if you keep adding new stuff to it :)  (And debian releases are the same, I believe)
but i think debian releases are spaced out a lot more
Yes, so you have even *older* packages :P
But you would, wouldn't you?  Unless your running debian unstable, you'll have a released version that doesn't get new packages.

i assumed that for example Debian is at 4.0, while 4.0 is stable (which should be for a while), packages will be updated for it, so i'll be able to update gnupg for example until next Debian is released
No, that's not the way it works.  Packages *don't* get updated, otherwise it's not a release.  New packages break new things :)
whereas if Ubuntu releases a new stable every six months, i have to upgrade every six months in order to update packages i currently have
Similar to Ubuntu.  People who run Etch (4.0) will have Gnome 2.16 for the entire life of etch.
but if Gnome was updated while Etch was stable, wouldn't an updated package be released for it?
*No*.  Because then Etch wouldn't be a release :)
hmm, i think i understand
Gnome has *already* been updated, it get's updated every 6 months. (Hence the Ubuntu release cycles) :)

what puzzles me is that say for example 7.04 was just released and let's say that a major vulnerability was found in gnupg or some other sensitive app, you would be stuck with that vulnerable app until the next ubuntu release (if using packages exclusively)
No, that's not true.  There'd be a fixed package in the feisty-security repository.
Packages get security fixes always, and (simple) bugfixes generally.  But never (well, almost never) by using a new upstream version.
thanks for clearing it up
You might want to ask jdong and the backports team to backport the package you're after, though.
